posts.author: KailPendragon
posts.content:
EliHarel wrote:I'm not following. Why does taking 15 Cleric levels pre-epic exploit DP to its fullest?
It's not about 15 Clerics, it's about 15 BAB at lvl 20. Having BAB 15 at lvl 20 means you get 3 APR. Divine Power will raise your BAB to the BAB of a FTR of the same level as your character; if that increase means you get more APR than you would get without the spell, then the extra attacks will iterate starting from max AB. So with 15 BAB (3 APR, attacks per round), you get +5 AB from DP and an extra attack (your fourth attack in the round) at full AB. With 16 BAB instead, you would get +4 AB from DP (for the same final result) and no extra attack since you already have 4 APR; the 4th attack in the round will, evidently, be made at -15 AB.

A practical example of the attack progression, let's assume no WF and let's skip the STR bonus to AB:

Cleric 17/FTR 3, with no buffs (BAB 15): 15/10/5
Cleric 16/FTR 4, with no buffs (BAB 16): 16/11/6/1

Cleric 17/FTR 3, with DP active (+5 BAB): 20/15/10/20
Cleric 16/FTR 4, with DP active (+4 BAB): 20/15/10/5

The 4th attack at full AB vs -15 AB makes a HUGE difference.

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
EliHarel wrote:I ask again - is discipline not that important?
For melee, of course it is. But this is a feat- and skill-starved build so one needs to be prudent to get the most bang for their buck with the few available.

So you have 2 choices as I see it: 1) Ignore discipline entirely or 2) max it and use skill focus feats to boost it to a level where it will actually help to avoid KD/IKD, disarm & called shots from high strength, high AB foes. DEX focus just puts you in too deep a hole to dig out of it to make much use of the skill. If you concentrate on buffs/equipment to boost STR to make discipline more effective, all you will do is choke off your AB or other boosts. Sure, you may avoid the occasional low-level orc barbarian from taking advantage, but in the long run and at advanced levels, it won't provide much for the investment. If you calculate the DCs it should become readily evident what percentage of saves will occur with a pedestrian base discipline.

So then ask yourself "Which skill(s) will provide a more reliable benefit?"... and then allocate accordingly.

I happen to know the "exploit" that did happen and got fixed post 1.68. It has to do with DP but not directly. It's about the stacking of multiple extra attacks when you have many sources of it: DP, Haste and Rapid Shot or Flurry of Blows.

Pre 1.68, if your full ab was 40 (and your pre-epic BAB of 15), here is how it would look:

+40/+35/+30/+40/+40/+40.

All three extra attacks would come at full BAB, well actually it'd be +38 because Rapid Shot and Flurry of Blows both take away 2 AB to work, but you get the point anyway.

Post 1.69, what they did was add each extra attack at -5 from the previous one, so it became:

+40/+35/+30/+40/+35/+30

basically that was an exploit with multiple extra attacks all being at full BAB, but if you get only 1 extra attack, it is at full BAB. If you have perma-haste, the extra attack from DP effectively comes at -5 from full BAB, because Haste already grants you an extra attack at full BAB.

Take it EZ!

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
Richelieu wrote:
However, If you were a fighter class with full bab your fourth attack wouldnt be at full ab would it? Still seems like kind of an exploit to me, even if it is much less of one than it used to be.
It's not so much that it is a fighter type-class nuance, it's just the basic dynamic of BAB. At 16, the 4th APR shows up in the progression by virtue of that particular BAB rather than the class used to reach that level. Naturally, a pure fighter-type reaching BABs over 15 will get less of an advantage from DP than a multiclass that doesn't. For that matter, depending on how you view it, an intentionally-designed low strength build can "exploit" the benefits of DP even more than others with the autoboost to 18 STR.

Interpreting the term "exploit" can become an exercise in semantics when it comes to building because in many cases it can simply be "maximizing potential" depending on one's personal bias(es). It is difficult to recognize what the original designers of the game intended by setting up the dynamics they did. In a few cases, they realized the imbalance that certain interactions caused and corrected them via patches (as described by Max, above). Further balancing attempts have been made by custom content designers to achieve what THEY personally feel is better. I never experienced any further customizations of DP's functionality anywhere (though it's not out of the realm of possibility) so I must assume that most folks are satisfied with how it works as part of the cleric arsenal and therefore not exploitation in the majority sense.
